Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A Multi-Axis Repair System (MARS)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop a Multi-Axis Repair System (MARS), which is an automated precision alignment and repair planner and driver. MARS will make repair processes much more cost-effective and robust. Insufficient automation in current repair processes is the biggest hurdle in achieving cost-effective repairs with consistency. Due to the complexity of part damage, manual operations are widely performed, which introduces inconsistencies in repair quality. This project will demonstrate the feasibility to develop an efficient and robust planning and control system for precision alignment and repair of a damaged part. A unique centroid-axis alignment algorithm can automate the critical alignment procedure in the repeated repair practice. Adaptive contour printing can precisely and efficiently select deposition parameters and predict deposition height thus will be adaptable to local contour for effective repair. The successful implementation of MARS will result in an automatic and robust repair technology -- the most critical requirement in parts repair.

The commercial potential of this project is a dramatic improvement in cost-effectiveness, repair consistency, and energy footprint. MARS enables batch repair technology, lowers the technology threshold for personnel education and provides a quick response to a repair request. Therefore many repair businesses can be established to serve the local market by delivering consistent repaired parts. As a result, in addition to repairing high value components, medium value parts, such as machine tools or small damaged parts, will be applicable. The repair technology will be an environmentally friendly process by dramatically reducing the usage of raw material, energy input and industrial waste to produce new parts. MARS is a green repair process designed to meet the current sustainable manufacturing challenge, giving it great commercial potential.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project researched and developed an innovative Multi-Axis Repair System, or MARS, an automated precision alignment and repair planner and driver. MARS makes the repair processes much more cost-effective and robust. The objective of this Phase I research project is to explore the feasibility of developing MARS to automatically and effectively conduct precision alignment and drive a multi-axis system for repair. The project enables the current direct laser deposition systems and hybrid systems which integrate laser deposition and machining to repair parts with various damage conditions.

Intellectual Merit: Due to the complexity of part damage, manual operations are widely performed, which introduces inconsistency in repair quality. This research demonstrated the feasibility to develop an efficient and robust planning and control system for precision alignment and repair of a damaged part. A unique centroid-axis alignment algorithm automates the critical alignment procedure in the repeated repair practice. Adaptive contour printing precisely and efficiently selects deposition parameters and predict deposition height thus will be adaptable to local contour for effective repair. This proposed project is built on the success of the results of several federally funded research projects to provide a real impact. The industrial partners provided field applications and repair quality assessment. 

Broader Impact:The project has investigated the enabling technology and brought fully automated precision alignment and multi-axis control capability into the repair industry to restore damaged parts. Such a capability can lead to dramatic improvement in cost-effectiveness and repair consistency. With automation, MARS enables batch repair technology, lowers the technology threshold for personnel education and provides a quick response to a repair request. Therefore many repair businesses can be established to serve the local market by delivering consistent repaired parts. As a result, in addition to repairing high value components, medium value parts, such as machine tools or small damaged parts, will be applicable. Thus, this proposed project can greatly broaden the scope of repair opportunities and thus provide a significant impact to society. This repair technology is an environmentally friendly process by dramatically reducing the usage of raw material, energy input and industrial waste to produce new parts. MARS is a green repair process designed to meet the current sustainable manufacturing challenge, giving it great commercial potential. Several students will be involved in testing the proposed MARS concept. The proposed research and development activities and the resulting product commercialization experience will also be documented as case studies for use in several product realization classes to provide an impact on education.

Outcoming summary

The goal of this SBIR Phase I project was to explore the feasibility of developing an efficient system using automated alignment methods based on centroidal axis and image feature extraction as well as adaptive contour printing technology. The characteristics of MARS addressed in this Phase I project are summarized below:

1. The simplicity of automated alignment using geometric index, centroidal axis and image feature extraction makes the repair, modification, and coating processes easier.

2.Adaptive contour printing technology makes repair, modification, and coating readily available to be applied on various surfaces.
